raw_text:
Kinnock to urge reform in Lords
 
 Neil Kinnock has said his acceptance of a seat in the House of Lords will allow him to help "achieve further progress with substantial democratic reform."
 
 On the BBC's Breakfast with Frost it was put to Mr Kinnock that he had once referred to Lords members as "brigands, muggers, bribers and gangsters". But the outgoing European Commissioner said his comments - made some 26 years ago - needed to be put in context. He said advocates for reform needed to be inside the Lords to vote for it. "It was pointed out to me that if the additional democratic reform is going to take place it is going to require advocates in the Lords and people there willing to vote for it."
 
 Mr Kinnock added that the second factor behind his acceptance of the peerage was his appointment as chairman of the British Council. "History demonstrates that it's immensely useful for the British Council to have its chairman in the House of Lords and that was a conclusive factor." Mr Kinnock said he thought about the decision for "quite a long time" because he had long had reservations about the Lords. But he added: "The process of reform has developed substantially but not sufficiently, and consequently I did take all these factors into consideration because it's not a decision to be made glibly." The former Labour leader said he would probably take the title of Lord Kinnock of Bedwellty - his first constituency for which he was selected in 1969.
llama3.2:1b: Neil Kinnock accepted a seat in the House of Lords due to two factors: his advocacy for democratic reform and his appointment as chairman of the British Council, both of which suggest he would vote in favor of reform if presented with such an opportunity.
llama3.2:3b: Neil Kinnock accepted a seat in the House of Lords, stating it will help achieve substantial democratic reform and allowing him to vote for changes.
He downplayed past criticism of Lords members as "brigands" by saying advocates for reform need to be inside the Lords to support it.
His decision was influenced by his appointment as chairman of the British Council and a long consideration process.
gemma2:2b: Neil Kinnock will use his seat in the House of Lords to advocate for substantial democratic reform and become chairman of the British Council.
He acknowledges past criticism of the House of Lords but believes it's crucial for reform efforts to have advocates within it who can vote on changes.
He emphasizes that the decision wasn't made lightly, weighing various factors, including history and his long-held reservations about the institution.
qwen2.5:0.5b: A former British prime minister has urged the House of Lords and its members to continue reform, emphasizing that the House is not a mere "brigands" or "bribers" but an essential mechanism for advancing democratic reforms.
He believes that his acceptance of the peerage as Lord Kinnock of Bedwellty will make it easier for future generations to hold the House accountable and implement necessary amendments.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Neil Kinnock, accepting a Lords seat to push for democratic reform alongside advocates within the body.
His decision included considering his British Council chairman role and longstanding reservations about the House of Lords process.
qwen2.5:3b: Neil Kinnock has accepted a peerage but will use his House of Lords seat to advocate for democratic reform, despite previous criticisms.
He argues that advocates need to be inside the Lords to support reforms.
His acceptance is also influenced by being appointed chairman of the British Council, seen as useful for the institution.
While he initially had reservations about the Lords, reform has not been sufficiently advanced.
He will take the title Lord Kinnock of Bedwellty, his first constituency.
opencoder:1.5b: Kinnock, a member of the Lords, has expressed reservations about taking the seat of the House of Lords because it could increase democratic reform by advocating for significant progress.
Mr Kinnock added that if a stronger approach to democratic reform is enacted, advocates within the Lords would likely vote for it and thus contribute to its development.
This is also reflected in his decision for the British Council, where he madeappointed chairman.
smollm:1.7b: The summary is concise and objective, preserving key ideas and details from the original text.
It does not provide explanations or justifications for the content, but rather presents a factual account of the events and statements made by Neil Kinnock.
The summary focuses on the main points of the text, without adding any additional information or analysis.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Neil Kinnock has accepted a seat in the House of Lords, which allows him to help achieve "further progress with substantial democratic reform."
His comments earlier were made 26 years ago but need to be contexted.
He emphasized that reform requires advocates within the Lords and people there willing to vote for it.
Additionally, he added that his appointment as chairman of the British Council is a factor in this decision.

He thought about the title for quite a long time because of past reservations but ultimately took the title of Lord Kinnock of Bedwellty after considering various factors, including the development of reform.
tinyllama:1.1b:
Kinnock Urges Reform at Lord's, Says Acceptance Was Based on Advocacy for Democratically-Approved Progress

Neil Kinnock has said his acceptance of a seat in the House of Lords will allow him to help further progress with substantial democratic reform.
Speaking on the BBC's Breakfast With Frost, he noted that his comments were made around 26 years ago and had been put into context by advocates for such reforms.
Kinnock said that advocacy was necessary because those in positions of power "would need to vote" for the additional reform.
He added that his appointment as chairman of the British Council helped solidify this stance, as it demonstrated its value for the Council's work.
Despite having reservationd about the House of Lords in the past, Kinnock said he took all factors into consideration when deciding to take up his seat.
He eventually chose to take on the role of Lord Kinnocmck of Bedwellty, his first constituency for which he was selected in 1969.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Kinnock has been nominated for a seat in the House of Lords to advocate for substantial democratic reform, according to recent news reports.
This new appointment will allow him to work on behalf of the British Council and have a say on how they operate within Parliament.
His long-standing concerns about the role of the Lords as an obstacle to meaningful reform were weighed against his desire to make a difference within the institution.

In his opinion, having a seat in the House of Lords would be beneficial to British politics by giving advocates for democratic change an opportunity to influence decision-making processes and hold those in power accountable.
phi:2.7b: Neil Kinnock accepts a seat in the House of Lords to help achieve further progress with democratic reform, despite facing criticism in the past for comments made 26 years ago.
He believes advocates for reform need to be inside the Lords and voted on it.
Mr. Kinnock is also accepting the appointment as chairman of the British Council, which will provide immense value to them both.

He believes advocates for reform need to be inside the Lords to vote for it, and his appointment as chairman of the British Council was a deciding factor in his decision.
hermes3:3b: Neil Kinnock plans to accept Lords seat to promote democratic reform, claims advocates need to be inside to vote for it; also appointed as British Council chairman.

Kinnock added that his appointment as chairman of the British Council played a significant role in his decision, along with considering other factors.

He acknowledged past criticisms of the Lords but argued that reform advocates needed to be inside to effect change.
Another factor in his decision was his appointment as chairman of the British Council, as history showed the role benefited from a presence in the Lords.
Kinnock admitted he deliberated for a long time due to his reservations but concluded that reform had progressed, though not sufficiently.
He is likely to take the title Lord Kinnock of Bedwellty.
stablelm2:1.6b: Neil Kinnock, who accepted a seat in the House of Lords, aims to help with substantial democratic reform and advocate for change within the organization.
In an interview on BBC's Breakfast with Frost, Kinnock clarified his previous comments about Lords members as necessary for understanding why he agreed to hold the title.
He also mentioned his appointment as chairman of the British Council as a crucial factor in his decision.
Kinnock believes the reform process requires advocates inside the Lords and acknowledges that it might not have developed sufficiently.
Despite his reservations, he intends to take the title of Lord Kinnock of Bedwellty, reflecting his first constituency for which he was selected in 1999.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Neil Kinnock, former European Commissioner and long-time critic of the House of Lords, has accepted a seat to facilitate substantial democratic reform within the institution.

He acknowledges past characterizations of Lords members as "brigands, muggers, bribers, and gangsters," but emphasizes that such stances were made in context, highlighting the need for reform advocates to be physically present in the Lords to vote for change.
Kinnock's decision was also influenced by his appointment as chairman of the British Council, which benefits from having its leader in the House of Lords.
After careful consideration due to his reservations about the Lords, he will likely adopt the title Lord Kinnock of Bedwellty, marking a return to his first constituency where he was elected in 1969.
